Documentation¶

Data¶

class data_type.Data(source=None)¶

Bases: object

This is the abstract class inherited by data type classes.

Parameters

source (str) – Reference to the data source (e.g. a csv or connection string)

convert_data(key, old_dtype, new_dtype)¶

Convert data from one dtype to another.

Parameters

  • key (str) – Key in data to be converted

  • old_dtype (str) – Dtype to be converted from

  • new_dtype (str) – Dtype to be converted to

Returns

converted data

convert_dtype(key, old_dtype, new_dtype)¶

Set data and dtypes to reflect dtype conversions

Parameters

  • key (str) – Key in data to be converted

  • old_dtype (str) – Dtype to be converted from

  • new_dtype (str) – Dtype to be converted to

Tabular¶

class data_type.Tabular(source=None, num_bins=15, num_points_per_bin=None)¶

Bases: data_type.Data

This is the class used for handling tabular data. Data from either a csv or data base connection will be converted to a pandas dataframe.

Parameters

  • source (str) – Reference to the data source (e.g. a csv or connection string)

  • num_bins (int) – Number of bins to use when converting from numeric to ordinal

  • num_points_per_bin (int) – Number of points per bin to use when converting from numeric to ordinal

bin_numeric(column, num_bins=15, num_points_per_bin=None)¶

Bin numeric column

Parameters

  • column (str) – The column to bin

  • num_bins (int) – Number of bins to use when converting from numeric to ordinal

  • num_points_per_bin (int) – Number of points per bin to use when converting from numeric to ordinal

convert_data(column, old_dtype, new_dtype)¶

Convert data from one dtype to another. Currently only numeric to ordinal.

Parameters

  • column (str) – The column in data to be converted

  • old_dtype (str) – Dtype to be converted from

  • new_dtype (str) – Dtype to be converted to

Returns

converted data

extract(data=None, dtypes=None)¶

Set data from either csv or postgresql table, or from passed dataframe

Parameters

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Dataframe to set as data, reads from source if this is None

  • dtypes (dict) – Dictionary mapping columns to dtypes if data is not None, can be inferred if data is not None

Predicate¶

class predicate.Predicate(keys, mask=None, score=None, adjacent=None)¶

Bases: object

Abstract class for predicate object.

Parameters

  • keys (list) – Variables covered by this predicate, dependent on type of data (e.g. columns for Tabular)

  • mask – Returns subset when applied to data

  • score (dict) – Dictionary of scores, any of which can be used during predicate induction

  • adjacent (dict) – Dictionary mapping each key to a list of any adjacent predicates along that axis

allowed_dtypes = ['nominal', 'ordinal', 'numeric']¶
allowed_dtypes_map = {}¶
get_mask(data)¶

Return a mask that will return a subset when applied to the data.

Parameters

data – Data to return mask for

Returns

mask

get_mask_cached(data)¶

Return a mask that will return a subset when applied to the data. Get the cached results if available.

Parameters

data – Data to return mask for

Returns

mask

Parameters

  • data – Data to get score for

  • score_f (function) – Function used to calculate score

Returns

score

Initialize data across the given keys.

Parameters

  • data – Raw data to be initialized

  • data_type (data_type.Data) – Data type class

  • allowed_dtypes (list) – List of allowed data types

  • allowed_dtypes_map (dict) – Dictionary mapping data types to allowed data types

  • dtypes (dict) – Dictionary mapping keys to dtype

  • keys (list) – List of keys to include

is_adjacent(key, predicate)¶

Check if the given predicate is adjacent to this predicate along the given axis.

Parameters

  • key (str) – Axis along which predicates are adjacent

  • predicate – Adjacent predicate of the same type

Returns

Whether or not the given predicate is adjacent along the given axis

Return type

bool

is_contained(key, predicate)¶

Check if this predicate is contained by the given predicate along the given axis.

Parameters

  • key (str) – Check along this axis whether this predicate is contained

  • predicate – Predicate of the same type that will be checked to see if it contains this predicate

Returns

Whether or not this predicate is contained by the given predicate along the given axis

Return type

bool

is_subsumed(key, predicate, data, score_f)¶

Check if this predicate is subsumed by the given predicate along the given axis for the given scoring function. A predicate is subsumed by another if it is both contained along the given axis and has a lower score.

Parameters

  • key (str) – Check along this axis whether this predicate is subsumed

  • predicate – Predicate of the same type that will be checked to see if it subsumes this predicate

  • data – Data to get score for

  • score_f (function) – Function used to calculate score

Returns

Whether or not this predicate is subsumed by the given predicate along the given axis

Return type

bool

is_subsumed_any(key, accepted, data, score_f)¶

Check if this predicate is subsumed by any of a list of predicates across the given axis for the given scoring function.

Parameters

  • key (str) – Check along this axis whether this predicate is subsumed

  • accepted (list) – Lost of predicates of the same type that will be checked to see if it subsumes this predicate

  • data – Data to get score for

  • score_f (function) – Function used to calculate score

Returns

Whether or not this predicate is subsumed by any of the given predicate along the given axis

Return type

bool

is_subsumed_any_all_keys(accepted, data, score_f)¶

Check if this predicate is subsumed by any of a list or predicates across all keys for the given scoring function.

Parameters

  • accepted (list) – Lost of predicates of the same type that will be checked to see if it subsumes this predicate

  • data – Data to get score for

  • score_f (function) – Function used to calculate score

Returns

Whether or not this predicate is subsumed

Return type

bool

Merge this predicate with the given predicate

Parameters

  • predicate – Predicate of the same type to merge with

  • data – Data to calculate score and mask for merged predicate

Returns

Merged predicate

set_adjacent(key, predicate)¶

Set this predicate and the given predicate to be adjacent to each other along the axis of the given key.

Parameters

  • key (str) – Axis along which predicates are adjacent

  • predicate – Adjacent predicate of the same type

Set given predicate to be adjacent to this predicate along the axis of the given key.

Parameters

  • key (str) – Axis along which predicates are adjacent

  • predicate – Adjacent predicate of the same type

Conjunction¶

class predicate.Conjunction(column_to_values, dtypes, data=None, column_to_mask=None, mask=None, score=None, adjacent=None)¶

Bases: predicate.Predicate

This class defines subsets of data as a conjunction over tabular data.

Parameters

  • columns_to_values – Dictionary of lists mapping columns in the data set to values defining a subset of the data

  • dtypes (dict) – Dictionary mapping columns to dtypes

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Dataframe that this predicate will take a subset of

  • column_to_mask (dict) – Dictionary mapping columns to a mask for each column, will be recalculated if None

  • mask (np.array, pd.Series) – Returns subset when applied to data

  • score (dict) – Dictionary of scores, any of which can be used during predicate induction

  • adjacent (dict) – Dictionary mapping each key to a list of any adjacent predicates along that axis

allowed_dtypes = ['nominal', 'ordinal']¶
allowed_dtypes_map = {'numeric': 'ordinal'}¶
static bottom_up_init(data_obj=None, data=None, dtypes=None, columns=None)¶

Initialized predicates for bottom up predicate induction.

Parameters

  • data_obj (Data) – Data object used to initialize predicates, will be generated from data and dtypes if None

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Data to initialize base predicates from if no data_obj is provided

  • dtypes (dict) – Dictionary mapping columns to dtype if no data_obj is provided

  • columns (list) – List of columns to include

Returns

List of predicates

Return type

list

PredicateInduction¶

class predicate_induction.PredicateInduction(data, base_predicates, score_f, frontier_predicates=None)¶

Bases: object

Abstract class for predicate induction object.

Parameters

  • data – Data to search

  • base_predicates (list) – List of predicates to begin search

  • score_f (function) – Function used to score predicates

  • frontier_predicates (list) – List of predicates to continue search from, set to base_predicates if None

expand_frontier(expand_f, verbose=False)¶

Expand the current frontier given an expansion function.

Parameters

expand_f (function) – The function used to expand the current frontier

expand_frontier_nsteps(n, verbose=False)¶

Expand the current frontier for a given number of steps

Parameters

n (int) – Number of steps to expand the frontier

get_predicate_score(predicate)¶

Return score for the given predicate

Parameters

predicate (Predicate) – Predicate to score

greedy_merge(predicates, verbose=False)¶

Merge a list of predicates.

Parameters

  • predicates (list) – List of predicates to merge

  • verbose (bool) – Option to print messages

Returns

List of merged predicates

Return type

list

greedy_merge_predicate(predicate, predicates, verbose=False)¶

Merge a given predicate with a list of other predicates.

Parameters

  • predicate (Predicate) – Predicate to merge with other predicates

  • predicates – List of predicates to merge

:type predicates list :param verbose: Option to print messages :type verbose: bool

greedy_merge_step(predicates, verbose=False)¶

A single step of merging a list of predicates.

Parameters

  • predicates (list) – List of predicates to merge

  • verbose (bool) – Option to print messages

Returns

List of merged predicates

Return type

list

insert_sorted(queue, predicate, accepted=[], verbose=False)¶

Insert the given predicate into the given queue in sorted order.

Parameters

  • queue (list) – List of predicates to insert into

  • predicate (Predicate) – Predicate to insert

  • accepted (list) – List of predicates that will be checked against to see if the predicate being inserted is subsumed

  • verbose (bool) – Option to print messages

update_predicate_frontier(frontier_predicates, predicate, children)¶

Update the current frontier given a predicate and its children. If the predicate has not children and has a score greater than the set threshold it will be added to the list of accepted predicates. Otherwise its children will be added to the list of frontier predicates.

Parameters

  • frontier_predicates (list) – Current list of frontier predicates

  • predicate (Predicate) – Original predicate

  • children (list) – Children of original predicate

BottomUp¶

class predicate_induction.BottomUp(data, base_predicates, score_f, frontier_predicates=None)¶

Bases: predicate_induction.PredicateInduction

This class is for performing bottom up predicate induction. This method involves beginning with a large number of predicates, each covering a small space of the data, and merging predicates into a smaller number each covering a larger space.

Parameters

  • data – Data to search

  • base_predicates (list) – List of predicates to begin search

  • score_f (function) – Function used to score predicates

  • frontier_predicates (list) – List of predicates to continue search from, set to base_predicates if None

apply_all_keys(predicate, keys, f, accepted=None, verbose=False)¶

Apply a function to all keys included in a given predicate.

Parameters

  • predicate (Predicate) – Predicate that the function will be applied to

  • keys (list) – List of keys

  • f (function) – Function to apply to the given predicate

  • accepted (list) – List of predicates that will be checked against to see if the predicate being inserted is subsumed

  • verbose (bool) – Option to print messages

Returns

New predicates

Return type

list

Expand the current frontier for one step.

  • verbose (bool) – Option to print messages
